author: By David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Curbs Nuclear Inspectors, but Appears to Leave Space for a Deal
description: The new limits appeared to be lighter than the country had threatened, giving Western nations three months to see if they can revive the 2015 nuclear agreement.
content: Iran appears to have partly lifted its threat to sharply limit international inspections of its nuclear facilities starting on Tuesday, giving Western nations three months to see if the beginnings of a new diplomatic initiative with the United States and Europe will restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Just When You Thought Politics Couldn’t Unravel Any Further
description: What happens when “All the King’s Men” meets “National Lampoon’s Vacation”? Nothing good.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, my favorite recent political story was Ted Cruz’s Terrible Vacation. Partly because it made Ted look like such a jerk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Hake and Monkfish From the Source
description: Maine fishing groups join forces to bring their seafood to the public.
content: Hake, related to cod, and monkfish, sturdy and easy to cook, might not dominate your shopping list like salmon. But with fewer restaurants ordering because of the pandemic, the fishermen hauling in these varieties off the Maine coast need you to buy them. A collaboration to encourage their use, between the Maine Coast Fishermen’s Association, a trade group; Gulf of Maine Sashimi, a high-end processor; Island Institute, a nonprofit Maine community group; and Luke’s Lobster, a restaurant chain; are making the fish available nationwide, flash-frozen, at Luke’s online store. Luke Holden, an owner of Luke’s Lobster, is serving the fish at his flagship restaurant in Portland, Maine, but said his other locations were too small to allow for the preparation. Hake is delicious sautéed or poached; monkfish is great in stews and takes to sautéing. They’re selling each fish in two one-pound packages, $60 for hake, $55 for monkfish and $18 shipping. Purchases also support Fishermen Feeding Mainers, for people in need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: France Hired McKinsey to Help in the Pandemic. Then Came the Questions.
description: After previously undisclosed contracts were revealed, the company has become a magnet for criticism in France’s vaccine rollout.
content: PARIS — As France raced to complete a complex blueprint in December for vaccinating its population against the coronavirus, the government quietly issued millions of euros in contracts to the consulting giant McKinsey & Company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Lucky Luke, the Comic Book Cowboy, Discovers Race, Belatedly
description: For the first time in the Franco-Belgian comic book classic, Black characters have full-fledged roles and are drawn without the racist depictions that marred the genre.
content: PARIS — A few years ago, Julien Berjeaut was a cartoonist coming off a hit series when he received the rarest of offers in the French-speaking world: taking over a comic book classic, Lucky Luke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Plowy McPlowface Has a Shot in Naming Contest. ‘Abolish ICE’ Does Not.
description: The Minnesota Transportation Department excluded that one as too political. The public can vote on 50 finalists, including Raspberry Brrr-et, Road Carew and Mary Tyler More Snow.
content: The suggestions came in by the thousands, with the inevitable puns and nods to Prince, Minnesota Twins legends and, of course, snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Literary Community Cookbook
description: Tables of Contents, an organization founded by the chef Evan Hanczor, has released its first cookbook.
content: Among the programs that provide thought for food is Tables of Contents, an organization founded in 2012 by the chef Evan Hanczor, of Egg in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Among its activities are dinners inspired by literary works, both classics like “The Sun Also Rises,” and, starting in 2016, new works with food references read by their authors. Mr. Hanczor does the cooking. The group also publishes a monthly newsletter. And now it has the bright new “Tables of Contents Community Cookbook,” containing 41 recipes from literary contributors, accompanied by excerpts and some art. They include Eileen Myles’s recipe for falafel; Angela Flournoy’s collard greens braised in coconut milk; Alexander Chee’s turkey aloo keema; and Helen Phillips’s grapenut custard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Fraud Checks and Errors Slow Small-Business Relief Loans
description: The renewed Paycheck Protection Program has disbursed $140 billion this year, but many applicants have had to wait weeks for lenders to resolve problems.
content: The problems plaguing those seeking loans from the government’s revived small-business relief program have ranged from simple to shocking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Did Washington Just Have an Actual Weekend?
description: President Biden is uninterested in generating headlines, which only emphasizes how the Trump-size hole in Washington has created a sense of free time in the capital — psychically, if not literally.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden did not do anything this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Grenache, or Garnacha: Same Grape, 3 Ways
description: If you take a single variety and make wine in three distinct regions, how different will the wines be?
content: How important is the choice of grape in determining the character of a wine?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Tough Sanctions, Then a Mysterious Last-Minute Turnabout
description: The Treasury Department slapped sanctions on the Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler in 2017 for corruption in Africa. In Donald Trump’s final days in office, they were rolled back with no explanation.
content: WASHINGTON — In early December, an Israeli billionaire named Dan Gertler made an unusual request to the Treasury Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Viet Thanh Nguyen Packs Plenty of Action and Outrage Into ‘The Committed’
description: This sequel to the Pulitzer Prize-winning “The Sympathizer” finds its unnamed narrator in France, considering the relationship between that country and Vietnam.
content: If I’m a boat person, thinks the narrator of Viet Thanh Nguyen’s “The Committed,” so were the English Pilgrims who came to America on the Mayflower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Chicken Parm, Form of a Sausage
description: Seemore’s latest flavor pays tribute to an Italian-American favorite.
content: Seemore Meats and Veggies, a company run by Cara Nicoletti, a fourth-generation butcher, fills its casings with a high proportion of vegetables to meat. It has just introduced a clever variety, chicken Parm. Each link delivers a flavor-packed mosaic of ground chicken, roasted tomatoes, cheese, bread crumbs and basil. Sear or grill them whole and serve alongside pasta, or in a sandwich, or slice into coins and sauté to toss into a pasta sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Nevada Is Moving to Vote Before Iowa in 2024. Harry Reid Makes the Case.
description: Goodbye, Iowa and New Hampshire. Hello, Nevada and South Carolina? The former Nevada senator is just one voice arguing that it’s time to change the nomination calendar.
content: For generations, Iowa and New Hampshire have held a special place in American politics, as the first states to vote in the Democratic and Republican presidential nomination process. The candidates flock there well before election year for steak fries and county fairs, endless town halls and glad handling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Watch Video From NASA’s Perseverance Rover Landing on Mars
description: The spacecraft has sent pictures, audio and video recordings to Earth since it landed on Mars last Thursday.
content: What is it like to land on Mars?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: F.C.C. Broadband Plan Includes $50 Monthly Subsidy for Millions
description: A proposal released by the acting chairwoman of the commission is an attempt to close the digital divide.
content: The acting chairwoman of the Federal Communications Commission on Monday announced a proposal to use $3.2 billion in emergency funds to significantly subsidize broadband service for millions of households, an attempt to narrow the digital divide that has punished low-income families during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: England will reopen schools in two weeks, but pubs and restaurants will stay shut for now, Johnson says.
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson introduced a “road map” to end lockdown restrictions, the tentative first steps in a long-awaited plan to ease a nationwide lockdown prompted by a highly contagious variant of the coronavirus.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said Monday that schools in England would reopen on March 8 and that people would be allowed to socialize outdoors starting on March 29, the tentative first steps in a long-awaited plan to ease a nationwide lockdown prompted by a highly contagious variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Schengen Area closes up.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Upper East Side Source for Hamantaschen
description: Butterfield Market has the small, buttery cookies from the pastry chefs Mark Fiorentino and Claudio Miolin.
content: Purim, one of the happiest Jewish holidays, is coming up at sundown on Thursday. Essential to the celebration are hamantaschen, triangular cookies that are plump with fillings like apricot, poppy seed and even some savory combinations. Gastronome Bakery, opened by Jonathan Weizman as a pandemic-inspired offshoot of his wholesale prepared food and catering company, has Mark Fiorentino, who once worked for Daniel Boulud, and Claudio Miolin, formerly at Pasquale Jones, baking them. Butterfield Market on the Upper East Side is selling the apricot, raspberry and Nutella-filled small, buttery hamantaschen, $16 for nine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Rwanda Opposition Figure Is Killed in South Africa
description: South African authorities said that for now they were treating the case as a robbery, but the political allies of the man who was shot, Seif Bamporiki, had their suspicions of an assassination.
content: CAPE TOWN, South Africa — A Rwandan opposition figure was shot and killed in South Africa on Sunday in what the police said was most likely a robbery but that political allies said resembled earlier assassinations of government critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: An anti-N.R.A. ad campaign focuses on the group’s own members.
description: A new advertising campaign from Everytown for Gun Safety is targeted at an unusual demographic for an organization that promotes stricter gun laws: card-carrying, dues-paying members of the National Rifle Association.
content: A new advertising campaign from Everytown for Gun Safety is targeted at an unusual demographic for an organization that promotes stricter gun laws: card-carrying, dues-paying members of the National Rifle Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The 4 Great Migrations
description: America as we have come to know it is most likely a thing of the past.
content: The humanitarian and infrastructure disaster that followed Texas’ winter storm illustrates that catastrophic weather events may soon become less freak occurrences and more part of an unremitting new normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj
title: Do India’s Cows Have Special Powers? Government Curriculum Is Ridiculed
description: The Hindu nationalist government postponed plans for a national student exam on cows that critics said used specious claims and substituted religion for science.
content: NEW DELHI — Indian students were hitting the books hard in preparation for a big test on cows, reading that India’s cows have more emotions than foreign ones, and that their humps have special powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Judith Levitt
title: 500,000 Deaths, Trump Taxes, Digital Art: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: On Federal Appeals Courts, a Spike in Partisanship
description: Partisan alignments used to be rare when full appeals courts reconsidered the decisions of three-judge panels. But that changed in the Trump era.
content: WASHINGTON — For many decades, there was little evidence of partisan behavior in what can be the most bare-knuckled power play in the federal judicial system: when all the active judges on a federal appeals court reconsider the decisions of three-judge panels of their colleagues, a practice that lawyers call en banc review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and Benjamin Weiser
title: Here’s What’s Next in the Trump Taxes Investigation
description: A Supreme Court ruling has paved the way for prosecutors to begin combing through Mr. Trump’s financial records.
content: Terabytes of data. Dozens of prosecutors, investigators and forensic accountants sifting through millions of pages of financial documents. An outside consulting firm drilling down on the arcana of commercial real estate and tax strategies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Johnson Lays Out a Cautious Path for Leaving the Lockdown
description: Having confused and angered Britons in the early stages of the pandemic, he is determined to make the step-by-step plan “irreversible.”
content: LONDON — Britain, hit hard by the coronavirus but surprisingly successful in the race to vaccinate its people, embarked Monday on a new, more hopeful phase of the pandemic, as Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a step-by-step plan to reopen the economy, starting with schools on March 8.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 22, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 22, 2021.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 22, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: 4 Aid Workers Are Shot Dead in Pakistan
description: The attack could portend a resurgence of militant violence in the former tribal areas of Waziristan, once a hub of the Pakistani Taliban.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Gunmen killed four aid workers in an ambush in the northwestern Pakistani district of North Waziristan on Monday, police officials said, an attack that could signal a revival of insurgency in the region bordering Afghanistan that was once a stronghold of the Pakistani Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Woody Allen and Soon-Yi Previn Call HBO Docuseries a ‘Shoddy Hit Piece’
description: “Allen v. Farrow” revisits Dylan Farrow’s sexual abuse allegations. On Monday, Mr. Allen’s publisher said HBO also used his memoir without permission.
content: Shortly after the premiere of the first episode of “Allen v. Farrow,” an HBO documentary series that re-examines Dylan Farrow’s decades-old sexual abuse allegations against the filmmaker Woody Allen, her adoptive father, a spokesperson for Mr. Allen released a statement on Sunday night slamming the series, calling it a “shoddy hit piece.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve L. Ewing
title: Can We Stop Fighting About Charter Schools?
description: The real question for Democrats is how to get every student a good education.
content: As an education researcher, a writer and a former teacher, I’ve had the opportunity to talk with people all over the country about public schools. And wherever I go, there’s one question I can usually count on being asked:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Gender-Reveal Device Explodes, Killing Man in Upstate New York
description: The explosion in a garage killed Christopher Pekny and injured his brother on Sunday, officials said. Another brother described what happened as “the freakiest of freak accidents.”
content: A man who was expecting his first child was killed on Sunday and his brother was injured when a device they were preparing for a gender-reveal party exploded in a garage in the Catskills in New York, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Flowery, Yes. But the Wines of Fleurie Offer More.
description: It’s a wine that has long been typecast. Maybe now is the time to recognize that Beaujolais is no longer just one thing.
content: Years from now, when the history of Beaujolais is written, it will be fascinating to see how the wine is portrayed over the first part of the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Allen v. Farrow’ Episode 1 Recap: ‘Inappropriately Intense’ Behavior
description: The new HBO documentary series takes another look at Dylan Farrow’s sexual abuse allegations against her adoptive father, Woody Allen.
content: The first episode of the four-part HBO docuseries “Allen v. Farrow” debuted on Sunday night, providing a fresh examination of Dylan Farrow’s decades-old sexual abuse allegations against the filmmaker Woody Allen, her adoptive father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Rangers Star Takes Leave After Accusations He Assaulted a Woman in a Bar
description: Artemi Panarin denies the allegations made by a former K.H.L. coach. The team says their top scorer has been targeted for criticizing Vladimir Putin.
content: The New York Rangers on Monday vigorously defended their winger Artemi Panarin, even as he took a leave of absence amid allegations that he hit a woman in a bar a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Irish Whiskey Returns to Its Roots
description: Teeling uses peat to dry the barley for its Blackpitts whiskey, lending an air of smokiness to a smooth tipple.
content: Starting in the late 18th century there were whiskey distilleries clustered in Dublin. By the 1960s they were gone. It’s a complicated story, but now Dublin distilling is in revival mode. Teeling Whiskey, opened in 1782 by Walter Teeling, was reestablished near its original location in 2012 by the brothers Jack and Stephen Teeling, descendants of the founder. In 2015 they began producing a range of whiskeys. Their latest, called Blackpitts, has historic and uncommon character. Smoky peat was once used to dry the malted barley, and now a whiff of smokiness from that revived method overlays the subtly honeyed palate of this graceful new whiskey. It’s also on the light side, thanks to triple distillation, typical in Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: New York’s pop-up concerts kick off with jazz at a vaccination site.
description: It seemed at first like a small, no-frills concert in a carefully controlled environment: the jazz musician Jon Batiste sitting at a piano in an auditorium at the Javits Convention Center on Manhattan’s West Side, performing for an audience of about 50 health care workers — some wearing scrubs, others Army fatigues.
content: It seemed at first like a small, no-frills concert in a carefully controlled environment: the jazz musician Jon Batiste sitting at a piano in an auditorium at the Javits Convention Center on Manhattan’s West Side, performing for an audience of about 50 health care workers — some wearing scrubs, others Army fatigues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Grim U.S. milestone, but global signs of hope.
content: New cases, hospitalizations and deaths around the world have slowed drastically in the worst hotspots, with six countries accounting for most of the drop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Early data offers hope on AstraZeneca’s vaccine.
description: A study from Scotland shows a substantially reduced risk of hospitalization after a single shot. But experts caution more evidence is needed.
content: The first studies of Britain’s mass inoculation program showed strong evidence on Monday that the coronavirus vaccines were working as intended, offering among the clearest signs yet that the vaccines slash the rate of Covid-19 hospital admissions and may be reducing transmission of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Muhammad Ali as You’ve Never Seen Him
description: A new graphic novel mixes comic book art and rarely seen photography to depict the legendary 1974 fight between Ali and George Foreman.
content: Muhammad Ali, muscled, poised and with a punch ready to be thrown, is captured in a rarely seen photograph taken by Abbas Attar at the Rumble in the Jungle, one of the boxer’s most famous matches, in 1974. In the next moment, illustrated by Rafael Ortiz, Ali delivers the blow to George Foreman, and the panel seems to reverberate from its force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Lauren Hirsch
title: MyPillow C.E.O. Mike Lindell Sued by Dominion Over Election Fraud Claims
description: The complaint alleges that Mr. Lindell “exploited” false claims about election fraud to support sales of his own business.
content: Dominion Voting Systems sued Mike Lindell, chief executive of MyPillow, on Monday, alleging that he defamed Dominion with baseless claims of election fraud involving its voting machines. The company is seeking more than $1.3 billion in damages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Australian Open Offered Unexpected Lessons About Pandemic Sports
description: The goal was to hold a major international sports event without putting public health at risk. Mission accomplished, but pulling it off presented major, unforeseen challenges and many sleepless nights.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The leaders of the Australian Open wanted their intricate safety strategy to teach the sports world important lessons for the coronavirus pandemic: How to hold a major event with big crowds without worsening the dangers to public health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Billion-Dollar Paydays in a Pandemic
description: The top 25 hedge fund managers earned $32 billion last year, according to Institutional Investor’s latest rankings.
content: Today, Institutional Investor unveiled the 20th edition of its Rich List, one of the most watched rankings of hedge fund managers’ performance. Every year, financial tycoons pore over the magazine’s estimates of whose fortunes are up the most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: She Beat Cancer at 10. Now She’s Set to Be the Youngest American in Space.
description: St. Jude Hospital and Jared Isaacman, a billionaire entrepreneur, selected Hayley Arceneaux for a trip to orbit in a SpaceX capsule.
content: Hayley Arceneaux, 29, had hoped this would be the year that she would complete her aim of visiting all seven continents before she turned 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Bakery Crosses the East River
description: Sweet Generation relocates to a larger Bushwick, Brooklyn, facility.
content: When Amy Chasen opened Sweet Generation, her cupcake-size bakery in the East Village in 2014, she wanted to include a program that benefited society. Sweet Generation RISE, with internships for 16- to 24-year-olds to learn skills needed for food service careers, was born (and not connected to several other organizations also called RISE). It received a multimillion dollar grant from the city’s Criminal Justice Investment Initiative in 2017 for what it described as its work with “young people at risk of becoming involved in the justice system.” With the funding, Sweet Generation, known for Instagram-worthy cakes, cupcakes and cookies, has relocated to a significantly larger two-story space in Bushwick, Brooklyn, opening Saturday. Rob Valencia is the new executive chef in charge. It can now increase its repertoire, retail area and wholesale business, adding items like a French onion soup-flavored scone, assorted sandwiches, a vegan sticky bun and plant-based soft-serve. It will also expand its Sweet Generation RISE program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: torpor
description: This word has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Michael Gonchar
title: What ‘Old’ Technology Do You Think Is Cool?
description: Why do you think there is so much interest in obsolete technologies like Polaroid instant cameras, record players, Atari game systems or VHS tapes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Future of Texas
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: You can make a case that the U.S. state with the brightest long-term economic future is Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong’s top leader is inoculated ahead of a mass vaccination campaign.
description: Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, and other top officials received the Sinovac coronavirus vaccine on Monday as the semiautonomous Chinese territory prepares to begin its mass inoculation campaign this week.
content: Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, and other top officials received the Sinovac coronavirus vaccine on Monday as the semiautonomous Chinese territory prepares to begin its mass inoculation campaign this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Why Biden Is Tackling Immigration Now
description: With polls showing broad support for reform, Democrats want to pass major legislation — before 2022.
content: President Biden took a major step last week to slow deportations, and his allies in Congress unveiled a bill that would represent the country’s most sweeping immigration overhaul in generations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Black Hero With a Marshal’s Badge Rides Into a Classic Comic Book
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 22, 2021.
content: “While I was working on the United States, it made me think about Europe and France. It was like a kind of mirror. This history of slavery, it’s also our history, though differently. This history of racism, it’s also our history, though differently.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cheryl Maguire
title: Hello, Brains! A Life Spent Helping Others Understand A.D.H.D. Online
description: Jessica McCabe used YouTube to teach herself about A.D.H.D. Her videos taught others. Then she built a business.
content: Jessica McCabe, creator of the YouTube channel “How to A.D.H.D.,” is not a doctor or medical professional. At 38, she’s had a variety of professions including stand-up comedian, actor and restaurant server.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: For Maximum Flavor, Make These Spice Blends at Home
description: Grind these five versatile, beloved mixes ahead of time, then keep them on hand for cooking that’s full of verve and depth.
content: Savvy cooks across the globe know that one of the easiest ways to add verve to their cooking is to keep a selection of aromatic spice blends at the ready. From Chinese five spice to Cajun seasoning, from Indian masalas to Chilean merken, spice blends are the cornerstones of so many cuisines, with very good reason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Movie theaters in N.Y.C. can reopen with limited capacity late next week, Cuomo says.
description: The theaters will only be permitted to operate at 25 percent of their maximum capacity, with no more than 50 people per screening. Masks will be mandatory.
content: Movie theaters in New York City will be permitted to open for the first time in nearly a year on March 5, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced at a news conference on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Alan Rappeport
title: Tanden’s Confirmation on Shaky Ground as More Senators Voice Opposition
description: Two moderate Republican senators said they would not vote to confirm President Biden’s nominee to head the budget office, further dimming her chances of securing enough support.
content: WASHINGTON — Neera Tanden, President Biden’s nominee to head the Office of Management and Budget, suffered a significant setback on Monday as two moderate Republicans said they would not support her nomination, potentially dooming her chances for confirmation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery, Rick Rojas and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Texans Needed Food and Comfort After a Brutal Storm. As Usual, They Found It at H-E-B.
description: As state government flounders, has a beloved grocery store chain become “the moral center of Texas”?
content: AUSTIN, Texas — The past week had been a nightmare. A winter storm, one of the worst to hit Texas in a generation, robbed Lanita Generous of power, heat and water in her home. The food she had stored in her refrigerator and freezer had spoiled. She was down to her final five bottles of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Changes P.P.P. Rules to Help the Self-Employed
description: A more generous loan formula for solo ventures is meant to get more very small businesses into the Paycheck Protection Program. But bigger applicants face a two-week pause.
content: Aiming to put its own stamp on the Paycheck Protection Program, the Biden administration on Monday abruptly changed crucial program rules in ways intended to help the smallest and neediest companies, which have sometimes struggled to obtain aid from the federal relief effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Vanessa Friedman
title: Jay-Z and LVMH, Two of the World’s Biggest Brands, Go Into Business
description: LVMH, owner of Dom Pérignon, will acquire half of Armand de Brignac, Jay-Z’s Champagne line known as Ace of Spades.
content: When Jay-Z clicked into a video call last week with Philippe Schaus, the chief executive of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton’s drinks business, the Zoom backgrounds told the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Genoways
title: A Sweeping History of What We Eat
description: In “Animal, Vegetable, Junk,” Mark Bittman tells the long, unfolding story of our food sources, tracking the shift from agriculture to agribusiness.
content: ANIMAL, VEGETABLE, JUNKA History of Food, From Sustainable to SuicidalBy Mark Bittman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Fraud checks and errors slow small-business relief loans.
description: When the Paycheck Protection Program began last year, the Trump administration — eager to get money out the door as quickly as possible — eliminated most of the safeguards that normally accompany business loans. With applications approved almost instantly, thieves and ineligible borrowers siphoned billions of dollars from the $523 billion the program distributed last year.
content: When the Paycheck Protection Program began last year, the Trump administration — eager to get money out the door as quickly as possible — eliminated most of the safeguards that normally accompany business loans. With applications approved almost instantly, thieves and ineligible borrowers siphoned billions of dollars from the $523 billion the program distributed last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Why an Animated Flying Cat With a Pop-Tart Body Sold for Almost $600,000
description: A fast-growing market for digital art, ephemera and media is marrying the world’s taste for collectibles with cutting-edge technology.
content: In the 10 years since Chris Torres created Nyan Cat, an animated flying cat with a Pop-Tart body leaving a rainbow trail, the meme has been viewed and shared across the web hundreds of millions of times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Graham-McLay
title: 10 Years After Christchurch Quake, a Hush Where 8,000 Homes Once Stood
description: The wreckage left in New Zealand’s second-largest city was razed. Now, a swath nearly twice the size of Central Park is being reclaimed by nature.
content: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — First the houses and cars vanished. Fences, driveways and the other remaining markers of suburban life followed. Now, only stretches of green remain — an eerie memorial to two earthquakes that leveled Christchurch, New Zealand’s second-largest city, 10 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How far can you go with lab-made food substitutes? This reporter found out.
description: A slew of venture-backed companies envision a world where we sit down for dinner and brag that no animals were harmed in the production of this carbon-neutral porterhouse steak. They want to Impossible Burger our entire diet.
content: A slew of venture-backed companies envision a world where we sit down for dinner and brag that no animals were harmed in the production of this carbon-neutral porterhouse steak. They want to Impossible Burger our entire diet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How to Walk Safely in the Snow, Ice and Slush
description: Walk like a penguin: Turn your feet slightly outward and take short, flat-footed steps.
content: This has been a most challenging winter, especially for folks like me in their upper decades who’ve had to contend not only with pandemic-induced loneliness and limitations but also with streets piled high with snow and sidewalks coated with ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Uprising Grows Over Cuomo’s Bullying and ‘Brutalist Political Theater’
description: The scrutiny of Covid-19 deaths in New York nursing homes has also put the governor’s aggressive behavior in the spotlight.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — During Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s first term, two former administration officials were married in a New York City wedding heavily attended by state government workers, as well as some lawmakers and their aides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Imam and Alex Marshall
title: Giving Hope, and a Place to Mourn: Memorials to the Pandemic
description: How should we memorialize those who’ve died from Covid-19? In Italy and Britain, artists and architects are beginning to come up with answers.
content: CODOGNO, Italy — On Sunday afternoon, several hundred people gathered in the small town of Codogno, about 35 miles south of Milan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $880,000 Homes in California
description: A 1916 bungalow in Oakland, a penthouse loft in a converted theater in Long Beach and a ranch house in Pasadena.
content: This house sits between the Santa Fe neighborhood in Oakland and the city of Emeryville, about two miles from Bay Street Emeryville, a large mixed-use development with shopping and restaurants. A park with a recreation center and baseball field is a few blocks away, and the headquarters of Pixar Animation Studios is a five-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: A City With Amazon at the Center
description: What happened to California’s Inland Empire when Amazon came to town.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Portland Welcomes Monument (Origin Unknown) to Black Man Who Reached Pacific in 1805
description: City officials say they have no idea who raised a monument to York, the enslaved Black man who traveled with Lewis and Clark, in the park where a statue of a conservative Oregonian had stood.
content: Over two years, York trekked some 8,000 miles from St. Louis to the Pacific Northwest and back, hunting, tracking, foraging and, at least once, voting as a Black man held in bondage by another, more famous member of the Lewis and Clark expedition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak, William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and Benjamin Weiser
title: Supreme Court Denies Trump’s Final Bid to Block Release of Tax Returns
description: The former president’s accountants will give New York prosecutors the financial records he has spent years trying to shield.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday rejected a last-ditch attempt by former President Donald J. Trump to shield his financial records, issuing a brief, unsigned order that ended Mr. Trump’s bitter 18-month battle to stop prosecutors in Manhattan from poring over his tax returns as they investigate possible financial crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: The Virus Slammed Her Neighborhood. She Can’t Find Her Father a Vaccine.
description: Logistical hurdles, fear and misinformation are threatening to leave some of the city’s immigrant communities behind as the vaccine rollout ramps up.
content: Flora Pérez, a produce vendor in Queens, has been trying for weeks to get a vaccine appointment for her 82-year-old father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Despite Rebukes, Morgan Wallen Earns a Sixth Week at No. 1
description: The country star’s “Dangerous: The Double Album” continues to perform well on the Billboard chart, three weeks after he was caught on video using a racial slur.
content: For three weeks now, the music industry has agonized over what to do about Morgan Wallen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Guadagnino
title: Both Sides Now: In Conversation With Lorraine O’Grady
description: On the eve of her first major retrospective, the artist talks about her past, her process and the benefit of criticism.
content: In 1977, in a nod to the Surrealists, the conceptual artist Lorraine O’Grady started cutting phrases out of The New York Times and rearranging them into lines of poetry, which she glued, mostly slantwise, onto sheets of rag paper: “Dinner is reserved for/Twin Speech: A Language of Their Own” reads one spliced fragment. She was in her early 40s. Fifteen years earlier, O’Grady had worked as an intelligence analyst for the federal government. During the Cuban Missile Crisis, she was tasked with reading around 10 international newspapers a day and, as she likes to say, “at a certain point, words just became gelatinous.” But from that experience O’Grady was able to extract new meaning out of language. “I did a poem a week, and when I got to the four-month mark, they started taking off, and I could tell something was happening,” she says, though the knowledge that her own ideas could carry her from one place or plane to the next must have already been familiar. In addition to her time in Washington D. C., her pre-artist life included stints as a translator, a teacher, a student of fiction at the Iowa Writers’ Workshop and, as if she weren’t already intimidating enough, a rock critic. “I don’t feel I’ve had much unlived life,” says O’Grady, now 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland, Katie Thomas and Carl Zimmer
title: Vaccines Adapted for Variants Will Not Need Lengthy Testing, F.D.A. Says
description: The agency’s new guidance will speed the development of vaccines that protect against more contagious variants of the coronavirus.
content: The Food and Drug Administration said on Monday that vaccine developers would not need to conduct lengthy randomized controlled trials for vaccines that have been adapted to protect against concerning coronavirus variants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Washington
title: 50 Million Americans Are Unpaid Caregivers. We Need Help.
description: Biden must make good on his promise to support families with sick loved ones.
content: Five years ago I stood in a tiny hospital room wondering how I was going to care for the man I loved most without succumbing to despair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Katie Glueck and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Bagel Orders and Vaccine Appointments: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race
description: A former City Council speaker decides not to run, and a current city comptroller becomes the first leading candidate to get the coronavirus vaccine.
content: The horde of politicians running for mayor of New York City appears to have finally hit a saturation point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Clifford Krauss
title: What’s Really Behind Corporate Promises on Climate Change?
description: Many big businesses have not set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Others have weak goals.
content: For the past several years, BlackRock, the giant investment firm, has cast itself as a champion of the transition to clean energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Lessons on Resilience From Dogs and Dog Sledders
description: The adventurer Blair Braverman has led a team of sled dogs over a 900-mile race in Alaska, seen her skin dissolve in the desert and overcome Covid-19. What makes it all less terrifying? Accepting the unknown.
content: In the midst of a pandemic, everyday life can feel like an endurance event. Enter Blair Braverman, a dog racer, writer and an adventurer who has built a career surviving harsh conditions. Her advice? A critical part of the race is making sure you rest along the way. “Just think to the next checkpoint,” she says, “whatever your next goal is.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What Yogurt Can Do for You
description: Once you start to make your own, you may find it hard to stop.
content: Good morning. I’m not sure why homemade yogurt (above) didn’t take off this year the way sourdough bread did, the way kombucha kind of did. As Melissa Clark demonstrates, it’s so simple to make, “and the payback is huge: a pot of tangy, silky yogurt made with ingredients you can control and personalized to your tastes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: South Africa Variant Emerges in New York
description: Coronavirus cases are declining in the state, but uncertainties remain about new dangers and the pace of vaccination.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: ‘Like We’re Being Cursed’: First Covid and Now Waterlogged Homes
description: Basics remain scarce in some parts of Texas, and many already battered by a year of the coronavirus now face a costly recovery.
content: KILLEEN, Texas — After her pipes burst and flooded her house, after she spent one night on a church couch and another fleeing a four-alarm fire in the hotel where she and her husband sought refuge, Janet Culver, 88, finally made it home a week after Texas’ epic winter nightmare began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Fernando Hidalgo, Cuban-Born TV Host, Dies at 78
description: For 14 years, “El Show de Fernando Hidalgo,” a racy variety show with a Cuban flair, was appointment viewing in Latino households across the United States.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italian Ambassador Among Three Killed in Attack on U.N. Convoy in Congo
description: The attack, on a World Food Program convoy headed to a school in North Kivu Province, left the ambassador, Luca Attanasio, an Italian embassy official and a driver dead.
content: For Luca Attanasio, Italy’s ambassador to the Democratic Republic of Congo, humanitarian work was at the core of his mission. The 43-year-old had moved with his wife to the capital, Kinshasa, in 2017, where their family grew to include three young daughters. He rose to the rank of ambassador in 2019, the pinnacle of his diplomatic career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Storm Victims Didn’t Bring It on Themselves
description: Disasters call for compassion and action, not sniping on social media.
content: NASHVILLE — Last week’s fierce winter storms didn’t change all that much at our house. We got mostly snow and sleet here, not freezing rain, so we never lost power. The roads were a catastrophic mess, but our refrigerator and cupboards were full — it’s a time-honored Southern tradition to clear store shelves of milk and bread when the forecast calls for even a flake of snow — and we didn’t have to risk our lives to get to work because we can do our work from home. We were lucky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Boryana Dzhambazova
title: Bulgaria offers a vaccine to anyone who wants one, and long lines form.
description: When vaccines arrived this winter in Bulgaria, which had one of the highest excess mortality rates in Europe, the authorities hoped people would clamor for a shot.
content: When vaccines arrived this winter in Bulgaria, which had one of the highest excess mortality rates in Europe, the authorities hoped people would clamor for a shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Candy Gets a Brand Extension
description: When did we become a nation of Willy Wonkas?
content: When Robyn Blair Davidson, 34, was envisioning an aesthetic for her New York City apartment two years ago, her eyes wandered over to a bowl of candy on her table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
title: U.S. Arrests El Chapo’s Wife, Charging Her With Helping to Run Drug Empire
description: Emma Coronel Aispuro, who had been under investigation for at least two years, was also charged with plotting to break her husband, Mexico’s most notorious drug kingpin, out of prison.
content: Emma Coronel Aispuro, the wife of Mexico’s most notorious drug trafficker, best known as El Chapo, was arrested Monday and charged with helping her husband run his multibillion-dollar criminal empire and plotting to break him out of prison after he was captured in 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Avalanche Warnings Are Issued in Northwest
description: The warnings came as heavier-than-usual rainfall and snowfall was expected to hit parts of Washington and Oregon.
content: Two avalanche warnings have been issued for parts of Washington and Oregon as heavier-than-usual rainfall and snowfall is expected to hit part of the West Coast through Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Vaccines Sharply Cut Coronavirus Hospitalization, U.K. Studies Show
description: The Pfizer-BioNTech and AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccines are both effective, and work against the more contagious virus variant in Britain, researchers found.
content: LONDON — The first studies of Britain’s mass inoculation program showed strong evidence on Monday that the coronavirus vaccines were working as intended, offering among the clearest signs yet that the vaccines slash the rate of Covid-19 hospital admissions and may be reducing transmission of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: In ‘Superman & Lois,’ the Heroes Face a New Menace: Teenagers
description: In a joint interview, Elizabeth Tulloch and Tyler Hoechlin talk about playing the latest version of the power couple, who in this new CW series are dealing with more relatable threats.
content: There is a line of dialogue in the opening episode of “Superman & Lois,” premiering Tuesday on the CW, that sums up the latest depiction of this storied super-romance. Lois Lane (portrayed by Elizabeth Tulloch) tells Clark Kent (played by Tyler Hoechlin), the alter ego of the Man of Steel, “No one ever dreams about the problems, but every life has them — even the extraordinary ones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: State Lawmakers Defy Governors in a Covid-Era Battle for Power
description: Legislators across the country, mostly Republicans, are moving to strip the powers of governors, many of them Democrats, who have taken on extraordinary authority to fight the pandemic.
content: Partisan warfare over pandemic lockdowns and mask-wearing is on the wane in Washington: A bitter presidential election has been decided, coronavirus cases are plummeting nationally and vaccines are rolling out slowly but steadily.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Legacy of Rush Limbaugh
description: The conservative radio host, who died last week, seeded an entire media ecosystem — and reshaped the American right.
content: The talk radio host Rush Limbaugh died last week. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Why Top Economists Are Citing a Higher-Than-Reported Jobless Rate
description: The official rate stood at 6.3 percent in January, but using an expanded metric, Fed and Treasury officials say it’s closer to 10 percent.
content: America’s official unemployment rate has declined sharply after rocketing up last year, but top government economic officials are increasingly citing a different figure — one that puts the jobless rate at nearly 10 percent, well above its official 6.3 percent reading and roughly matching its 2009 peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Carafes
description: Because even if you’re just drinking tap water, it’s more fun when you pour it out of a carafe.
content: Whether you’re serving cocktails, wine or water, pouring the drinks out of a striking carafe makes it feel a little more special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: New Jersey will soon allow some fans to attend events at venues with over 5,000 seats, Murphy says.
description: The state, following a similar move by New York, loosens restrictions for sports and entertainment. Still, safety protocols remain.
content: New Jersey, home to several major league sports teams, will allow a limited number of fans to attend sports and entertainment events at venues with 5,000 or more seats as soon as next week, Gov. Philip D. Murphy said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel G. Nesmith
title: Douglas Turner Ward, Pioneer in Black Theater, Dies at 90
description: A founder of the Negro Ensemble Company in New York in the 1960s, he was outspoken about limited opportunities for fellow Black actors and directors.
content: Douglas Turner Ward, an actor, playwright and director who co-founded the celebrated Negro Ensemble Company, a New York theater group that supported Black writers and actors at a time when there were few opportunities for them, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Cases on Abortion Referrals and Immigration
description: The cases, both challenges to Trump administration initiatives, may become moot if the Biden administration reverses course.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to rule on two Trump administration initiatives: one placing limits on a federal health program in an effort to restrict access to abortions, and the other denying green cards to immigrants who were considered likely to make occasional use of public benefits like food stamps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Weibel
title: This Bolognese May Be Meatless, but It Has Good Bones
description: This vegan take on hearty tomato sauce tastes as rich as the original and satisfies comfort-food cravings.
content: Some cooks may balk at a vegan version of Bolognese because it bypasses the beef and milk that are usually integral to the Italian classic. But there is a particular thrill to capturing the spirit of a traditional ragù without the traditional ingredients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Europe Wants to Diversify Its Pool of Astronauts
description: In its first hiring drive in over a decade, the continent’s space agency is looking to recruit disabled people and more women.
content: BRUSSELS — In a rare opportunity for Europeans dreaming of leaving the mundane duties of life on Earth, the European Space Agency is recruiting new astronauts for the first time in over a decade, with more diversity as the goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Sheri Fink
title: Lessons From Los Angeles’s Deadly Winter
description: Monday: A Times reporter who spent days inside Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital at the height of the surge discusses what we should learn.
content: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Fight Over Deb Haaland, First Native American Cabinet Pick, Reflects Partisan Divide
description: President Biden’s choice for interior secretary faces her confirmation hearing on Tuesday. Democrats see her as embodying the hopes of the new administration; Republicans object to her activism.
content: WASHINGTON — When Representative Deb Haaland was tapped in December to be President Biden’s interior secretary, the decision was hailed as historic. She was the first Native American ever nominated to serve in cabinet — in this case to head a department that, for much of the nation’s history, has mistreated and neglected Indigenous Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Bryan
title: How Britain Is Reacting to ‘It’s a Sin’
description: The show, which aired last month in the U.K., has broken a viewing record and revived conversations about how the country handled the AIDS crisis in the 1980s.
content: LONDON — In what may be a perfect formula for helping a well-made TV show go viral, all five episodes of “It’s a Sin” arrived on a British streaming service in late January, on the Friday before a snowy weekend, during a national lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Mr. Soul!’ and the Golden Globes
description: A documentary on the pioneering variety show “Soul!” is on PBS. And the Golden Globes air on NBC from both coasts.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 22-28. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can I Still Wear My Grandmother’s Fur?
description: Vanessa Friedman, fashion director of The New York Times, takes reader questions.
content: The evolution of the social contract and shared morality can have unexpected repercussions on fashion, relegating garments once considered essentials — like clothes cut to restrict women’s movements or cordon off social status — to the dustbin of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wayne A.I. Frederick
title: What Happens When People Stop Going to the Doctor? We’re About to Find Out
description: A year of missed preventive medical care is endangering minority communities.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has yet to end, but we are already beginning to feel the aftershocks. Even as thousands of Americans continue to die of Covid-19 every day, many people are suffering from serious health problems unrelated to the virus because their health care has been disrupted. With many Americans still afraid to go to hospitals and doctor’s offices, a second, more subtle pandemic is now looming because of the diseases that have gone undiagnosed and untreated since March 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Seismic Survey of Alaskan Arctic Refuge Won’t Move Forward
description: A missed deadline for flights to look for polar bears means the work to locate oil reserves the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is effectively killed.
content: An Alaska Native group failed to meet a critical deadline as part of its proposal to conduct a seismic survey in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, the Interior Department announced. The failure effectively kills the survey, which would have determined the location of oil and gas reserves in part of the refuge in anticipation of drilling there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: As cases surge, the French Riviera shuts down and tells people to stay away.
description: The French Riviera, the famed strip along the Mediterranean coast that includes jet-setting hot spots like Saint-Tropez and Cannes, will be locked down over the next two weekends in an attempt to fight back a sharp spike in coronavirus infections.
content: The French Riviera, the famed strip along the Mediterranean coast that includes jet-setting hot spots like Saint-Tropez and Cannes, will be locked down over the next two weekends in an attempt to fight back a sharp spike in coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: What Frances McDormand Would (and Wouldn’t) Give to ‘Nomadland’
description: The acclaimed film required her to draw from a life she prefers to keep private. So when the director asked to cast her family, too, the star pondered whether to cross a personal line.
content: It was a February day so overcast that noon looked like dusk, and Frances McDormand felt a little rattled. She told me this as we ambled down the main street of the small coastal town where she lives, a modest, hidden place so far from Hollywood that studio searchlights would have a hard time finding it. Still, someone had managed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: France’s vaccine contracts with McKinsey lead to questions for Macron.
description: As France raced to complete a complex blueprint in December for vaccinating its population, the government quietly issued millions of euros in contracts to the consulting giant McKinsey & Company.
content: As France raced to complete a complex blueprint in December for vaccinating its population, the government quietly issued millions of euros in contracts to the consulting giant McKinsey & Company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Joy Kaiser, Who Saw a Medical Need in South Africa, Dies at 90
description: With her husband, she founded an organization devoted to increasing the number of Black medical professionals. She died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Daft Punk Announces Breakup After 28 Years
description: The enigmatic, influential French electronic-music duo released four albums and collected six Grammys throughout a career marked by a disinterest in fame.
content: The enigmatic, pseudo-anonymous, retro-futuristic French electronic duo Daft Punk has broken up, the group announced on Monday in classic form — wordlessly, through music and iconography, in a YouTube video called “Epilogue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Feathers and Female Power: The Costumes of Carnival’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the history and role of costumes in Caribbean Carnival. Then, we invite them to respond artistically to the themes of transformation, history, ancestry and joy.
content: Featured Article: “Feathers and Female Power: The Costumes of Carnival.” Text by Ashley Southall with photographs and videos by Djeneba Aduayom
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Climate Threats Could Mean Big Jumps in Insurance Costs This Year
description: The federal government is revising rates for flood coverage on April 1. New data suggests premiums need to increase sharply for some homes.
content: WASHINGTON — The cost of federal flood insurance will need to increase significantly in much of the country to meet the growing risks of climate change, new data suggests, creating a political headache for the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Pennsylvania Election Case on Mailed Ballots
description: In dissent, three justices said the court should have used the case to provide guidance in future elections.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would not hear an appeal from Pennsylvania Republicans who sought to disqualify mailed ballots in the 2020 presidential election that arrived after Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew S. Lewis
title: She Rowed Across the Atlantic, Joining a New Wave of Extreme Endurance Athletes
description: After 70 days 3 hours 48 minutes, Jasmine Harrison, 21, became the youngest woman to row an ocean. She is among a diverse set of endurance athletes to attempt the feat.
content: By mid-January, Jasmine Harrison, a swim instructor and bartender, had been alone at sea for nearly 50 days. She had rowed 1,600 miles through the ill-tempered Atlantic Ocean and was only halfway there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: House Democrats Press Cable Providers on Election Fraud Claims
description: Before a hearing set for Wednesday, Democrats on the Energy and Commerce Committee asked cable companies what they did to combat “the spread of misinformation.”
content: Three months ago, federal lawmakers grilled Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, and Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief, about the misinformation that had appeared on their platforms. Now, a congressional committee has scheduled a hearing to focus on the role of companies that provide cable television service in the spread of falsehoods concerning the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin and Matthew Goldstein
title: A Donor’s Ties to Epstein Are Criticized at MoMA and Dartmouth
description: Ai Weiwei and other artists say the investor Leon Black should step down as MoMA’s chairman amid revelations that he paid $158 million to Jeffrey Epstein.
content: The artist Ai Weiwei said that he would ask the Museum of Modern Art to remove his works from its collection if the museum refuses to part ways with its chairman, the investor Leon Black, given recent revelations about the Wall Street executive’s close professional association with the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Researchers Halt Trials of Promising Sickle Cell Treatment
description: Two patients in a gene therapy study developed cancer years after treatment. It is not clear whether the therapy was responsible.
content: Just when it seemed that a new gene therapy for sickle cell disease was sailing toward success, the company developing the treatment found that two patients now have cancer and halted the trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Myanmar’s Protests Are Growing, Defying Threats and Snipers
description: A general strike on Monday made clear that the fatal shooting of two protesters over the weekend, and the fear of a further bloody crackdown, would not halt opposition to the return of military rule.
content: The strikers poured onto the streets of Myanmar on Monday knowing that they might die. But they gathered by the millions anyway, in the largest rallies since a military coup three weeks ago. Their only protection came from hard hats, holy amulets and the collective power of a newly called general strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Barry Le Va, Whose Floor-Bound Art Defied Boundaries, Dies at 79
description: Extolling horizontality, he made sculptures from felt, flour, glass sheets and even meat cleavers. Elsewhere, in a performance piece, his body was a sprinting projectile.
content: Barry Le Va, a sculptor who never bowed to the conventions of his medium, opting instead for temporary arrangements of ephemeral materials like felt and flour spread across the floor and, more flamboyantly, for works made by hurling meat cleavers, bricks and even his own body at walls, died on Jan. 24 in hospice care in the Bronx. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The U.S. approached a grim milestone: 500,000 deaths.
content: Roughly one year after the first known death by the coronavirus in the United States, the country is poised to reach a staggering milestone: 500,000 deaths from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Thomas
title: On Horseback Among the Eagle Hunters and Herders of the Mongolian Altai
description: Deep in the Altai Mountains, where Russia, China, Kazakhstan and Mongolia meet, Kazakh people have for centuries developed and nurtured a special bond with golden eagles.
content: Nine-year-old Dastan, the son of a Kazakh eagle hunter, rode his pony alongside mine, cantering effortlessly without a saddle and giggling at my attempts to show my fluffy pony some affection — a gesture that the animal wasn’t accustomed to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jed Kolko
title: The Jobs the Pandemic May Devastate
description: An updated forecast by the Bureau of Labor Statistics has alarming news for people with a high school diploma or less.
content: Projecting how many people will work in hundreds of detailed occupations in 2029 is a bold exercise — even without the uncertainty of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Buy a Real N95 Mask Online
description: Fakes and little-known brands still abound, even as health officials have advised us to up our mask game.
content: Fakes and little-known brands still abound, even as health officials have advised us to up our mask game.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Clubhouse, a Tiny Audio Chat App, Breaks Through
description: The 11-month-old app has exploded in popularity, even as it grapples with harassment, misinformation and privacy issues.
content: The 11-month-old app has exploded in popularity, even as it grapples with harassment, misinformation and privacy issues.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the United States Lost to Hackers
description: America’s biggest vulnerability in cyberwarfare is hubris.
content: America’s biggest vulnerability in cyberwarfare is hubris.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The President's Taxes
description: Long-concealed records show Trump's chronic losses and years of tax avoidance.
content: Long-concealed records show Trump's chronic losses and years of tax avoidance.

title: Amazon’s Great Labor Awakening
